lines.text: Akh je main tere na lai
lines.translation: Akh je main tere na lai
lines.grammar: The phrase "Akh je" is an idiomatic expression in Hindi, equivalent to "I swear" or "I assure you" in English, used to emphasize the speaker's sincerity. The verb "main" agrees with the subject "I" in number and case.

lines.grammar: This line is an idiomatic expression in Hokkien, a Chinese dialect. The phrase "ni menu" is an informal way to address someone, similar to saying "you guys" or "y'all" in English.

lines.text: Tere walo pawe koi pakka jeya karar ni
lines.translation: I have decided not to pack your feet.
lines.grammar: This line uses the present perfect tense (pawe) to indicate a completed action, and the idiomatic phrase "pakka jeya" means "to decide finally".

lines.text: Saha ch lako k rakhu tavi tera pyaar ni
lines.translation: I love you so much that I love you so much.
lines.grammar: This line uses a common idiomatic expression in Hindi, where the verb "rakhu" is used to emphasize the intensity of the feeling, equivalent to saying "so much" or "that much". The repetition of "love you so much" conveys the speaker's strong emotions.
